sci:arg.sci:help: Delimited string of Entity Types to be evaluated

sci:arg.name: Entity State
sci:arg.sci:help: Delimited string of Entity States to be evaluated

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Web Port to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: Reporting
sci:arg.sci:help: This group contains parameters specific to protocols containing Reporting components.

sci:arg.name: Reporting Stylesheet
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the name of a Stylesheet to be used by this protocol if any of the Reporting components have a Style selected in the Format and Position parameters.

sci:arg.name: Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: The Run On Grid parameter tells the server to run the protocol on the grid engine if SES is configured to run with grid integration.

sci:arg.name: Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The Queue Name allows you to specify the name of the queue on the grid engine to submit the job to. Leave blank to specify the default queue.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: WebExports
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties which will be automatically exported if this protocol is published as a web service.

Each global property in the list is created with an empty value at the start of the protocol run.

sci:arg.name: Keep Alive
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies if the process where this protocol is run should stay around for later use.

sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value:
This is your help window for working with components and protocols in Pipeline Pilot.

This window can display help about the protocol itself. You are currently viewing the default help text for a protocol. When you design and save a protocol, it is recommended that you change this text to specifically describe the protocol you have designed.

This window also displays help text for individual components and their parameters. To see help for a component, select an item from the Components tab or from within the protocol workspace. To see help about a parameter of a component, select one from the Parameter tab.

For more information, go to Getting Started with Pipeline Pilot.

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: OriginalPackage
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalPackage

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Data Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The SQL Database Data Source Name -- i.e. the specification of the database to be used by this SQL component. There are three choices: 1) The name of a pipeline pilot Data Source (DS Name). This data source is defined on the pipeline pilot server (using the Data Source Editor dialog from the client or the Administration Portal). The Data Source can reference either an ODBC or JDBC database connection. 2) The name of a connection defined on a previous SQL Open Connection component. Use the form (Name=Connection Name). Either the Data Source or Connection name can be specified from the dialog by clicking the '...' button 3) Alternatively this field can be an ODBC driver specification that eliminates the need to create a DSN or Data Source on the server. As an example: DRIVER=Scitegic Oracle 6.0;AUT=0;EDP=1;PRR=1;HOST=dbHost;UID=dbUser;PWD=dbPwd;PORT=1521;SID=dbSid (the AUT=0, ... settings reflect the correct defaults of 'Application Using Threads', 'Enable SQLDescribeParam' and 'Procedure Returns Results').

sci:arg.name: Authentication Method
sci:arg.sci:help:
Determines which method to use during authentication with the data source.
  • Use Username and Password Parameters: Use the values provided by the component's Data Source Username and Data Source Password parameters.
  • Use Pipeline Pilot Credentials: Use the username and password that were provided when the user logged into Pipeline Pilot. NOTE: if the Data Source Username parameter is provided, its value will override the user's logged in username.

sci:arg.name: Data Source Username
sci:arg.sci:help:
The username used to connect to the supplied Data Source.

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use Username and Password Parameters', then this parameter must be filled in to log into the database (unless it is part of the Data Source).

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use SciTegic Credentials', then this parameter can be left empty and the logged in user name is used. As an override option, if the user name is filled in, this user name will be used along with the user's Pipeline Pilot password.

sci:arg.name: Data Source Password
sci:arg.sci:help: The password used to authenticate with the Data Source. This parameter is disabled if Authentication Method is not set to 'Use Username and Password Parameters' or it is specified in the Data Source.

sci:arg.name: Connection Name
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify the name of this connection to conveniently use it from other SQL components without having to specify Data Source/Username, etc. Simply specify the Data Source parameter on these other SQL components as:

Name=Connection Name

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: Commit If Error
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines if records belonging to the same batch as a failing record are committed or not. If false and an error occurs, no records are committed to the database (any successful records before the error are rolled back and no attempt is made to operate on subsequent data records).

sci:arg.name: Initial SQL
sci:arg.sci:help:
An optional statement that is executed once right after the connection has been opened. A statement like this might be necessary for certain Oracle cartridges (like ISIS/direct). If the statement returns a result, this result is ignored. NOTE: It is also possible to specify an Initial SQL statement on the Data Source (using the Pipeline Pilot Admin Portal). This ensures that all users of the data source always get the initial SQL statement.
If both the Data Source and the SQL Open Connection component have an Initial SQL statement, the Data Source statement is executed first.

sci:arg.name: Cursor Type
sci:arg.sci:help: SQLServer connections can't handle multiple open result sets. If you encounter an error: "Connection is busy with results for another hstmt", set the Cursor Type to Static, to use the (slower) static instead of the default cursors.

sci:arg.name: RDBMS Supports Transactions
sci:arg.sci:help: Set this to false if the RDBMS you are connecting to does not support transactions. One RDBMS where support for transactions is optional is Informix.

sci:arg.name: Unicode
sci:arg.sci:help: Set this parameter to true to enable the retrieval of unicode, e.g. Kanji, characters. Set this to false to disable it.

sci:arg.name: JavaClass
sci:arg.sci:help: The class that implements the com.scitegic.pilot.Component interface.

sci:arg.name: Use Package
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the package that may be used to locate the Java binary files needed by the Java plug-in component.

sci:arg.name: DataActionOnError
sci:arg.sci:help: When a General or DataType error occurs during processing: LeaveData: The data is passed unalterd ClearData: The data is cleared before being passed (an empty data item) DeleteData: The data is deleted and not passed

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Opens an ODBC or JDBC database connection that can be shared by various SQL components in a protocol.

Specify the appropriate information to connect to your data source; at the least specify the Data Source and also if necessary the Authentication Method and Data Source Username and Data Source Password (if required). All additional components in the protocol that use the same Data Source (and optional authentication values) and have the Separate Connection parameter set to False will use this connection instead of having to open their own connection.

NOTE: Unless you need to specify any of the Additional Options (Commit If Error, Initial SQL, Cursor Type and RDBMS Supports Transactions) you do not need to use a SQL Open Connection component; simply specify the same Data Source for all SQL components that should share a connection.

NOTE: If an SQL Open Connection component is used to open the connection and an error occurs that halts the protocol, the current database transaction will be rolled back. If the connection is opened without using an SQL Open Connection component, the current transaction is committed upon any error that halts the protocol. This behavior is not affected by the Commit If Error parameter which only considers SQL errors against the database.

See Also:

  • For an overview of database integration, see the Database Integration Guide

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Database and Application Integration\Database Access\Advanced\SQL Open Connection

sci:arg.name: Data Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The SQL Database Data Source Name -- i.e. the specification of the database to be used by this SQL component. There are three choices: 1) The name of a pipeline pilot Data Source (DS Name). This data source is defined on the pipeline pilot server (using the Data Source Editor dialog from the client or the Administration Portal). The Data Source can reference either an ODBC or JDBC database connection. 2) The name of a connection defined on a previous SQL Open Connection component. Use the form (Name=Connection Name). Either the Data Source or Connection name can be specified from the dialog by clicking the '...' button 3) Alternatively this field can be an ODBC driver specification that eliminates the need to create a DSN or Data Source on the server. As an example: DRIVER=Scitegic Oracle 6.0;AUT=0;EDP=1;PRR=1;HOST=dbHost;UID=dbUser;PWD=dbPwd;PORT=1521;SID=dbSid (the AUT=0, ... settings reflect the correct defaults of 'Application Using Threads', 'Enable SQLDescribeParam' and 'Procedure Returns Results').

sci:arg.name: Authentication Method
sci:arg.sci:help:
Determines which method to use during authentication with the data source.
  • Use Username and Password Parameters: Use the values provided by the component's Data Source Username and Data Source Password parameters.
  • Use Pipeline Pilot Credentials: Use the username and password that were provided when the user logged into Pipeline Pilot. NOTE: if the Data Source Username parameter is provided, its value will override the user's logged in username.

sci:arg.name: Data Source Username
sci:arg.sci:help:
The username used to connect to the supplied Data Source.

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use Username and Password Parameters', then this parameter must be filled in to log into the database (unless it is part of the Data Source).

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use SciTegic Credentials', then this parameter can be left empty and the logged in user name is used. As an override option, if the user name is filled in, this user name will be used along with the user's Pipeline Pilot password.

sci:arg.name: Data Source Password
sci:arg.sci:help: The password used to authenticate with the Data Source. This parameter is disabled if Authentication Method is not set to 'Use Username and Password Parameters' or it is specified in the Data Source.

sci:arg.name: SQL Statement
sci:arg.sci:help:
An SQL Select statement with no parameter substitution e.g.
SELECT t1 from tab where c1 = 'yellow'
sci:arg.sci:value: SELECT site_id FROM entity_instances_index_view where entity_instance_id = $(Entity ID)

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to process (all if value is empty).

sci:arg.name: Select Behavior
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the SELECT statement returns multiple values. * Append Values: All values are appended onto array properties on one data record. (NULLs will be represented as empty values in the arrays). * Multiple Data: Multiple data records are returned, one for each SELECT record

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: Return Native Types
sci:arg.sci:help: If true, Pipeline Pilot creates a property with the type that matches the column type in the database. If false, Pipeline Pilot creates a property of type String.

sci:arg.name: Return Column Labels
sci:arg.sci:help:
If true, Pipeline Pilot creates result properties named by the SQL alias or label (default). Otherwise, Pipeline Pilot uses the native column names as the output property names based on the behavior of the JDBC driver. For instance, Oracle always returns the alias as the column name; however, MySQL and SAS/Share return different values. This setting applies only to JDBC connections. ODBC connections always use the column labels or aliases.

For example:

select a.foo as "bar", b.biz as "baz" from a, b where a.id = b.id

When "TRUE" returns:

barbaz
12

When "FALSE" returns:

foobiz
12

When executing joins across tables with the same column name, you must use Labels. For example, consider this SQL statement:

select a.foo, b.foo as "bar" from a, b where a.id = b.id

When "TRUE" returns:

foobar
12

When "FALSE" returns:

foo
2

sci:arg.name: Fetch Size
sci:arg.sci:help: When retrieving data from JDBC data sources, the Fetch Size can be specified to give a hint to the JDBC driver for now many rows to return from the database on each call. Setting this to large value (e.g. 1000) can use more memory and delay the return of the first record but will also significantly improve performance if the database is located over a high latency connection from the Pipeline Pilot Server.

sci:arg.name: Separate Connection
sci:arg.sci:help:
If True, create a separate connection for this SQL component irrespective of the Data Source and username/password. If False, all components in the complete protocol with the same Data Source and optional username/password (that have Separate Connection set to False) share the same database connection.

NOTE: in general it is recommended to keep this parameter False and have a single connection to avoid the overhead of opening and closing multiple connections. Also if some SQL components are placed into a Run to Completion sub protocol, it is recommended to have an SQL Open Connection component outside the subprotocol to avoid repeatedly opening and closing the database connection.

sci:arg.name: Unicode
sci:arg.sci:help: Set this parameter to true to enable the retrieval of unicode, e.g. Kanji, characters. Set this to false to disable it.

sci:arg.name: JavaClass
sci:arg.sci:help: The class that implements the com.scitegic.pilot.Component interface.

sci:arg.name: DataActionOnError
sci:arg.sci:help: When a General or DataType error occurs during processing: LeaveData: The data is passed unalterd ClearData: The data is cleared before being passed (an empty data item) DeleteData: The data is deleted and not passed

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Selects data records from an SQL (ODBC or JDBC) data source such as Oracle, MySQL or Microsoft SQL Server

Executes an SQL Select statement to select data records from a realtional database table. It is important that you modify the SQL statement so it uses the correct table and column names 
SELECT NAME, CITY FROM CUSTOMERS
WHERE CITY EQ 'San Diego'

See Also:

  • For an overview of database integration, see the Database Integration Guide

sci:arg.name: Expression
sci:arg.sci:help: Expression (or list of expressions separated by semi-colons) to evaluate.

sci:arg.name: Initial Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only the first time data passes into the component.

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only at finalization (after the last data passes out of the component).

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Keep Calculated Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: Adds any properties calculated in this component to a data record's property list.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Do Screen
sci:arg.sci:help: When TRUE, controls which exit port is used for each data record by evaluating the final expression (or only one) listed in the "Expression" parameter. -Pass (green) port when expression true -Fail (red) port when expression false

sci:arg.name: ExpressionVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: Version of expression parser to use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the maximum number of table rows in the HTML page

sci:arg.name: Rows Per Page
sci:arg.sci:help: The number of rows displayed on each page

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help: Lists a set of properties (without the @) to be created on the property list for this protocol. Other properties are created on the global property list and so are accessible from all protocols.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help: When the network is run, whether we process once or until done for each process call

sci:arg.sci:help: The optional title of the HTML document

sci:arg.name: Freeze Table Header
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this table's header and title will remain visible when the table is scrolled vertically.

Notes:

  • This feature only applies to HTML reports.
  • The fixed header behavior depends on what container (e.g., plain browser window, Tile component, Dynamic Content Container) that the Table is piped into.
  • To create a table of fixed pixel height, set this parameter to True and pipe this table into a Dynamic Content Container of fixed (i.e., non-percentage) height.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Displays data records as HTML in Internet Explorer

Generates and displays an HTML table page of data records, with one record per row. Each property becomes a column in the table and each value a cell.

Notes:

  • Molecules will be displayed if present.
  • For hierarchical data records, only top level properties are displayed.
  • Any grouped data is displayed in nested tables.
See Also:
  • If you prefer not to view the grouped data, use Delete Children.
  • For more control over the display of molecules, use HTML Molecular Table Viewer.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolMadeLinkIntoCopy
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Made Link Into Copy

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Data Access and Manipulation\Viewers\HTML Table Viewer

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value:
Use a subprotocol to collapse one or more components into a single item. Open a subprotocol to view or edit its contents.

To define input and output ports, display icon, and parameter settings, right-click and select Edit. You can save subprotocols and reuse them. For more information, see the User Guide help for Subprotocols Overview.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

Tip: Any component can be made into a shortcut, so that the latest version is always used. For more information, see Creating Shortcuts.
Records passing out of any unconnected pass ports of components inside the subprotocol
Records passing out of any unconnected fail ports of components inside the subprotocol

sci:arg.name: DelimitedText
sci:arg.sci:help: The contents of a delimited text file. This is a way to include a delimited text file in a protocol without sending an additional file.

sci:arg.name: Delimiter
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the character that separates fields. Options include:
- FigureOut: Determines the type automatically. - Tab: For tab-delimited fields. - Space: For space-delimited fields. - Comma: For comma-delimited fields. - Colon: For colon-delimited fields. - Semicolon: For semicolon-delimited fields.

sci:arg.name: MultipleValueDelimiter
sci:arg.sci:help: The delimiter to use between multiple values contained in a single property. If the multiple value delimited exists in any of the input strings in any property, they are separated into an array of values. If "None", values are never separated into multiple values.

sci:arg.name: HasColumnNames
sci:arg.sci:help: When True, property names are taken from the first line of data in the file. When False, properties are named Column1,Column2, etc.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help: Lists the set of temporary files which will be converted by the network to true temporary file names

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: WebExports
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma separated list of global properties which will be automatically exported if this protocol is published as a web service.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Webport to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentDisplayName
sci:arg.sci:value: Delimited Text Text Reader Read input XML

sci:arg.name: ProtocolAutoLayout
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.name: ComponentRevision
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Revision

sci:arg.name: ByReference
sci:arg.sci:help: By Ref

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Read Delimited Text kept with this component as a parameter value

This can be useful when you wish to send someone an example with the data contained with the protocol in a readable format. Just open the delimited file with a text viewer such as Notepad, copy the contents, and paste it into the DelimitedText parameter.

sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolMadeLinkIntoCopy
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Made Link Into Copy

sci:arg.name: Merge Behavior
sci:arg.sci:help: Options controlling the details of how properties are merged together

sci:arg.name: WhenMerging
sci:arg.sci:help:
Provides fine control over how multiple values are treated when merging data records together.

  • OverwriteOrCreate: Copies all properties of each merged record sequentially, overwriting any values that may already exist (instead of generating an array).
  • OverwriteExisting: Only copies properties that already exist on the first merged record, overwriting those original values (instead of creating an array).
  • CreateIfNew: Leaves any existing properties alone, and writes only new properties.
  • AppendOrCreate: Appends (as an array) if a property already exists, otherwise creates it.
  • AppendExisting: Appends (as an array) only to currently existing properties, and discards other new property values.

sci:arg.name: KeepAllNullString
sci:arg.sci:help: This string is used during append to pad out empty values. It keeps the number of values of generated arrays of values the same, and in sync, for multiple samples. The default value is None, which causes no padding to occur.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll'); Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: KeepAllPreferredNodeName
sci:arg.sci:help: If defined, this contains a name that is used to prioritize which underlying data record should be kept. If not defined, the first data record is kept; if this is defined, and at least one of the data records contains a node of this type, then the first example of that type is kept.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll'); Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: PrefixUsingProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: When multiple values for a property are retained, the original property name is prefixed differently for each original value it must hold. The prefix is constructed from the value of this property, followed by an underscore. When not specified, a prefix is not used and multiple values are separated as an array (such as property[1], property[2], etc).

sci:arg.name: OutputFrequency
sci:arg.sci:help: Add a property called "Frequency" that contains the number of individual data records included in the resulting merged record. This value is simply the total number of input records.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: MergeBehavior
sci:arg.sci:help:
Controls how properties, other than the MergeUsing property, are handled.

  • KeepAll: Keeps all property values by appending values into an array.
  • KeepFirst: Keeps only the properties and values from the first example received. All properties and values from subsequent records matching the property specified by MergeUsing are discarded.

sci:arg.name: MergeUsing
sci:arg.sci:help:
Name of the property (or a comma-separated list of properties) that will be used to merge on. Data records having the same value for this property will be merged. This property must contain scalar (i.e., non-array) data.

If multiple properties are specified, the values must be the same for all of the properties (unless MergeUsingListType is set to UseFirstDefinedValue).

sci:arg.name: MergeUsingListType
sci:arg.sci:help:
How MergeUsing properties are interpreted when more than one property is listed:

  • UseFirstDefinedValue: Use only the first property in the list that has a defined value for a record as the merge key.
  • UseAllValues: Use the concatentation of values of all properties listed as the merge key.

sci:arg.name: MergePropertyType
sci:arg.sci:help:
The types of values found in the property specified by MergeUsing:

  • IsNumeric: All numbers are converted to doubles for comparison (e.g., 1 = 1.0).
  • IsText: All comparisons are made as string values.
  • IsDate: The key is considered a date.
  • IsFingerprint: The key is considered a fingerprint. Fingerprint bits are sorted before making the comparison.

sci:arg.name: IgnoreCase
sci:arg.sci:help: Considers lower-case and upper-case letters as equivalent when determining the identity of MergeUsing property values.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergePropertyType to IsText'); Parameter('MergePropertyType') eq 'IsText'

sci:arg.name: AcceptNonNumericStringsAsNumbers
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines whether all string values for the MergeUsing property -- even non-numeric ones such as 'abc' or '1.0c' -- will be coerced to numbers when MergePropertyType is set to IsNumeric. If set to True, then a string such as 'abc' that does not begin with a numeric portion will be coerced to zero, while a string such as '1.0c' that begins with a numeric portion will be coerced to the corresponding number (in this case 1.0). If set to False, then records containing non-numeric strings for the MergeUsing property will be sent out the Fail port.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Merges properties of all input data records into a single output data record

Performs faster than Merge Data for the special case where all input records are to be merged into one. MergeBehavior controls how properties are handled.

See Also:

  • If you wish to merge data records that share identical values of a specified property, use Merge Data.
A single data record containing all merged properties of the input records

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ReplaceNullsInFirstRecord
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether to replace nulls in the first merged record when KeepAllNullString is specified.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Merge All
sci:arg.sci:help: Internal parameter indicating that all data records are to be merged into one, irrespective of the value of the MergeUsing Property.

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Data Access and Manipulation\Manipulators\Merge All Data

sci:arg.name: Expression
sci:arg.sci:help: Expression (or list of expressions separated by semi-colons) to evaluate.

sci:arg.name: Initial Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only the first time data passes into the component.

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only at finalization (after the last data passes out of the component).

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Keep Calculated Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: Adds any properties calculated in this component to a data record's property list.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Do Screen
sci:arg.sci:help: When TRUE, controls which exit port is used for each data record by evaluating the final expression (or only one) listed in the "Expression" parameter. -Pass (green) port when expression true -Fail (red) port when expression false

sci:arg.name: ExpressionVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: Version of expression parser to use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.sci:help: Expression (or list of expressions separated by semi-colons) to evaluate.

This expression is executed only the first time data passes into the component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The target URL to send the HTTP request.

sci:arg.name: HTTP Authentication Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Options for user credentials when the HTTP server requires authentication.

sci:arg.name: Authentication Method
sci:arg.sci:help:
Determines how to obtain the username and password for HTTP authentication.

  • Use Username and Password Parameters: Use the values provided by the component's Username and Password parameters.
  • Use Pipeline Pilot Credentials: Use the username and password that were provided when the user logged into Pipeline Pilot. In this case, the Password parameter is ignored. If left empty, the Username is ignored, but can be filled in to override the user's log-in name.

sci:arg.name: Username
sci:arg.sci:help:
The username used if authentication is needed for an HTTP server.

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use Username and Password Parameters', then this parameter can be filled in to provide authentication information to the remote server.

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use SciTegic Credentials', then this parameter can be left empty and the logged in username is used. As an override option, if the username is filled in, this username is used along with the user's Pipeline Pilot password.

sci:arg.name: Password
sci:arg.sci:help: The password to be used when authenticating to an HTTP server. This parameter is disabled if the Authentication Method is not 'Use Username and Password Parameters'.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("To enable, set Authentication Method to 'Use Username and Password Parameters'"); Parameter('Authentication Method') eq 'Use Username and Password Parameters';

sci:arg.name: Parameters
sci:arg.sci:help: The POST parameters to send to the server. You can add or remove additional parameters by clicking on the ... icon.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("To enable, set HTTP Method to 'Post'"); Trim(Parameter('HTTP Method')) eq 'Post';

sci:arg.name: Parameter 1
sci:arg.sci:help: Each POST parameter requires a name and value.

sci:arg.name: Parameter 1 Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the POST parameter to send to the remote server

sci:arg.name: Parameter 1 Value
sci:arg.sci:help: The value of the POST parameter. This can be any Pilotscript expression that returns a string. To specify a literal value, enclose it within quotation marks (for example, 'myvalue'). To specify a property name, type it in (for example, myproperty)

sci:arg.name: Additional Request Headers
sci:arg.sci:help: Optionally, you can add additional headers to the HTTP Post request to better control the behavior. On the HTTP request, the data sent in the headers is HeaderName: HeaderValue. For instance, to set HTTP Cookies on the request, set the header name of an additional request header to be Cookie and the value to CookieName=CookieValue; CookieName2=CookieValue2;

sci:arg.name: Header 1
sci:arg.sci:help: Each Additional Request Header requires a name and value.

sci:arg.name: Header 1 Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the Additional HTTP Request Header to send to the remote server.

sci:arg.name: Header 1 Value
sci:arg.sci:help: The value of the Additional HTTP Request Header.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: Put Response in Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the property to store the results from the server. The default is response

sci:arg.name: Maximum Property Size
sci:arg.sci:help: Set the maximum property size. When greater-than zero, the response is sent in one or more new data record properties, until the complete response has been consumed. When empty, the response is sent in one data record property.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: StrLength(Parameter('Put Response In Property')) > 0;

sci:arg.name: Include Response Headers
sci:arg.sci:help: If set to False, then the only data returned is the HTTP body from the response as indicated by the Put Response in Property parameter. If set to True, then each header on the response will be added as a property to the data record where the name of the property matches the name of the response header. Additionally, a property called HTTP Response contains the first line of the HTTP response headers that includes the HTTP version and HTTP response code.

sci:arg.name: Response is Binary
sci:arg.sci:help: set to True if the response data saved is binary. This will cause the type of the property to be set to SciTegic.value.ByteArrayValue and can be used in any component that takes binary data, such as the Binary Writer

sci:arg.name: Timeout
sci:arg.sci:help: The time in seconds to wait for a response from the server.

sci:arg.name: Connection Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Additional HTTP Connection options:

  • Allow Http Keep-alive connections (default: true). By default, most HTTP socket connections handle multiple requests to the server. You can disable this if you find that your connection is not handled as expected.
  • Allow the Http header, Expect: 100 (default: true). When sending a large body to the remote server, Expect 100 allows the remote server to respond mid-stream to inform the client that it needs to authenticate or redirect to a new URL. This can help the Http Connector component avoid sending large bodies to servers multiple times when it turns out that authentication is required or that the URL has been redirected.
  • Treat Http 403 responses as though a 401 response had been received instead (default: false). When a remote server requires authentication, it is supposed to return a response code of 401 to indicate that credentials are required. However, some servers erroneously send 403 responses instead. Some Http clients deal with this by preemptively sending authentication information. However, this presents a security hole, so this option allows the component developer to selectively send credentials to servers that are responding with 403 Forbidden as though they had actually responded with 401 Authenticate: Basic. It should only be used when it is clear that this will allow integration with a specific remote server.

sci:arg.name: HTTP Method
sci:arg.sci:help: The type of HTTP Method to use when sending the request. These include the standard HTTP Methods of Get, Post, Put, Head, Delete, Trace, Options, and Connect, but can also be an optional extended method, such as the WebDav method "Propfind".

sci:arg.name: HTTP Post Method
sci:arg.sci:help: The method to use when building the HTTP Request for the remote server, either "FormURLEncoded" or "FormMultipart".
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("To enable, set HTTP Method to 'Post'"); Parameter('HTTP Method') eq 'Post';

sci:arg.name: Additional Allowed Response Codes
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma separated list of HTTP response codes that are expected from the service. Ordinarily, Http response codes that indicate errors such as "500 Internal Server Error" and "403 Forbidden" are treated as errors by the component and a Pipeline Pilot error is generated. However, errors that can be handled internally by the component such as "401 Unauthorized" and "3xx Redirect" are dealt with. Note that some applications expect response codes and consider response codes to be part of the implementation.

For example, SOAP services often return "500 Internal Server Error" to indicate an error from the service itself that the client might be expecting. For these cases, you can specify a list of response codes such as "500,403" to tell the component to treat those responses as valid response codes.

The response codes that are already handled by the component are:

  • 100-199 (processing)
  • 200-299 (valid response)
  • 300-399 (redirect)
  • 401 (HTTP Authentication)
  • 407 (Proxy Authentication)
  • 417 (Expectation failed)

For the list of standard HTTP Response codes, see RFC 2616 (http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html). Extended response codes might also be available in other specifications.

sci:arg.name: Request Body
sci:arg.sci:help:
In lieu of specific Http Post parameters, you can also explicitly define the entire HTTP Request body here. Because it is an expression type, specify the name of a property that contains the text of the body.

If this parameter is specified, it overrides the contents of the Parameters group.

sci:arg.name: Maximum Response Size
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum amount of data in bytes to download from the server. The reponse data is truncated once the limit has been reached. If the parameter is blank, the limit is the default value of 64 MB.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Sends requests to an Http servers. It can also be used for executing and debugging various Http services such as REST and WebDav using methods such as Post, Get, Put, Head, Options

Configure this component to make remote POST calls to an HTTP server. The Source parameter specifies the URL for the location of the HTTP server to receive the POST request with the parameter names and values specified by this component. Alternatively, Additional Option parameters may be be configured to execute and consume other types of HTTP services, such as REST and WebDav. The component can either be the start of a new pipeline as a reader component or can be used within an existing pipeline to process multiple requests.

The HTTP request is configured based on the values entered for the Source parameter and either the Parameters group or the HTTP Method parameter combined with the Request Body parameter. If more than one parameter is needed, you can add additional parameters by pressing the "..." button. Parameter names and values are sent to the remote server using the encoding specified in the Http Post Method parameter. The response from the server is put into the property named by the Additional Options/Put Response in Property parameter, which is response by default. The handling of the http request and response can be further configured by using the Additional Request Headers and Additional Options groups of parameters, even to the degree of sending HTTP requests other than Post. See the individual help of each parameter for further information. If Additional Options/HTTP Method is anything other than Post or Additional Options/Request Body is specified, then the Parameters group is ignored.

Notes:

  • If the HTTP Method is Post, the post parameters must be provided in the Parameters group or in the Request Body parameter. If neither is provided, the component fails.
  • To set HTTP Cookies on the request, use the Additional Headers parameters and set the header name to Cookie and the value to CookieName=CookieValue; CookieName2=CookieValue2;
  • For remote servers that require HTTP authentication, set the Authentication Options parameters to provide username and password information either through parameters or through single sign-on from the Pipeline Pilot server to the remote server.
  • For performing basic HTTP Get requests that do not require any special headers or options, the majority of the standard file reader components such as the Text Reader and Binary Reader can read URLs as sources directly and the Copy File component can be used if HTTP authentication is required by the server.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Property Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the XML source property.

sci:arg.name: XML Repeat Tag
sci:arg.sci:help:
This parameter specifies the tag for the identification of an individual record for output. If this tag appears multiple times in the XML property data, multiple data records are output, one for each tag occurrence. If a tag is not specified, the entire XML content is read into a single record.

Note:

  • When encountering nested repeat tag elements, only the top level entry will be output. For example, if the repeat tag is "category", the following XML will return a single record:
    <category name="sec1"><category name="sec1-3"></category></category>

sci:arg.name: Properties Are
sci:arg.sci:help: If "Attributes" is selected, then attributes in the XML become properties of the containing element node. The attribute values become property string values. If "Leaf Elements" is selected, then leaf elements in the XML become properties on the parent element's node. The content of the leaf element becomes the property string value. Attributes are saved as metadata in the properties or nodes that are created.

sci:arg.name: Preserve Hierarchy
sci:arg.sci:help:
If True, the XML hierarchy is preserved as a series of data nodes and properties within each data record (which can then be accessed as deep properties). Any incoming properties are lost. If False, the XML hierarchy is flattened into a series of top level properties. When False, options for whether and how to pad missing values and attributes can be specified as well.

See Also:

  • For manipulating hierarchical data records, see the components under Data Access and Manipulation/Utilities/Data Tree Manipulators.

sci:arg.name: Pad Missing Values
sci:arg.sci:help:
When Preserve Hierarchy is False, multiple tags with the same name in the same tree are created as array properties. If this parameter is True, any difference in the number of tags at a specific depth will be corrected by padding the arrays with the string given in Padding Text. For example, given the following XML snippet: 
<a>

	<b>abc</b>

	<b>def</b>

	<c>123</c>

</a>

<a>

	<b>ghi</b>

	<d>456</d>

</a>
With Pad Missing Values set to False, these properties will be generated:
  • a/b: Array with 3 items: ['abc', 'def', 'ghi']
  • a/c: String with 1 item: '123'
  • a/d: String with 1 item: '456'

With Pad Missing Values set to True, these properties will be generated instead:

  • a/b: Array with 3 items: ['abc', 'def', 'ghi']
  • a/c: Array with 3 items: ['123', 'PADDING STRING', 'PADDING STRING']
  • a/d: Array with 3 items: ['PADDING STRING', 'PADDING STRING', '456']
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("Only enabled if Preserve Hierarchy is false"); not Parameter("Preserve Hierarchy");

sci:arg.name: Padding Text
sci:arg.sci:help: The string to use when padding arrays. By default, this is an empty string. However, if this causes confusion in your XML data, customize the string to something that can be uniquely identified.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('Only enabled if Pad Missing Values is True and Preserve Hierarchy is false'); Parameter('Pad Missing Values');

sci:arg.name: Pad Attributes
sci:arg.sci:help:
When flattening XML structures, in addition to padding missing tag values, it is often essential to pad attribute properties so that nested tags match up with their parent tag's attribute values. For instance, consider the following XML snippet: 

<a name="title" source="file">
	<b>abc</b>
	<b>def</b>
	<c>123</c>
</a>
<a name="author" location="San Diego">
	<b>ghi</b>
	<d>456</d>
</a>

With Pad Attributes set to False, these properties will be generated:

  • a.name: Array with 2 items: ['title', 'author']
  • a.source: String with 1 item: 'file'
  • a.location: String with 1 item: 'San Diego'
  • a/b: Array with 3 items: ['abc', 'def', 'ghi']
  • a/c: Array with 3 items: ['123', 'PADDING STRING', 'PADDING STRING']
  • a/d: Array with 3 items: ['PADDING STRING', 'PADDING STRING', '456']

With Pad Attributes set to True, these properties will be generated:

  • a.name: Array with 3 items: ['title', 'title', 'author']
  • a.source: Array with 3 items: ['file', 'file', 'PADDING STRING']
  • a.location: Array with 3 items: ['PADDING STRING', 'PADDING STRING', 'San Diego']
  • a/b: Array with 3 items: ['abc', 'def', 'ghi']
  • a/c: Array with 3 items: ['123', 'PADDING STRING', 'PADDING STRING']
  • a/d: Array with 3 items: ['PADDING STRING', 'PADDING STRING', '456']
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('Only enabled if Pad Missing Values is True and Preserve Hierarchy is false'); Parameter('Pad Missing Values');

sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Join Behavior
sci:arg.sci:help: How to merge the created data record with the incoming data record
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Preserve Hierarchy') eq 'True'

sci:arg.name: XML Repeat Level
sci:arg.sci:help: This parameter specifies the tag level for the identification of individual records appearing at that level in the XML document. If multiple elements appear at this level in the document, multiple data records are returned, one for each occurrence. If a tag level is not specified, the entire document is read into a single record.

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The file or URL source to read

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read.

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called "SourceTag" is created and holds the value indicated.
- None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
- Filename: The name of the file read.
- FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
- FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
- ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
- Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
- Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
- KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained. This parameter is ignored if Preserve Hierarchy is 'True'.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("To enable, set Preserve Hierarchy to false."); Parameter('Preserve Hierarchy') = false;

sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.sci:help: OnlyGenericData

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Generates data from generic XML supplied as an input data record property

The component reads the XML data from the input data record property specified by Property Name. The XML is broken into separate records based on the value of XML Repeat Tag. The XML between each of these tags up to its corresponding closing tag is treated as a single data record. The Properties Are parameter determines how the XML reader and writer interpret the XML.

Properties Are "Attributes"

  • Properties become string attributes
  • Nodes become elements
  • All metadata and property types are lost
Properties Are "Leaf Nodes"
  • Properties become childless elements
  • Nodes become elements with children
  • Metadata becomes attributes
  • Better preservation of information as metadata can contain typing information
Both operations are invertible, that is, the Data to XML component can use the same rules to reconstruct the object (except for noted lossyness in the former case).

Preserve Hierarchy determines whether the nested XML tree is formed into a series of nodes and properties or flattened into a single set of properties constructed by stringing together the element names delimited by a forward slash. Pad Missing Values and its grouped parameters determine whether and how to fill in missing tags and attributes when Preserve Hierarchy is False and the XML structure is flattened.

Example input data:

Consider reading in the following XML: 
<world>
  <region>
    <city>New York</city>
  </region>
  <region>
    <city>London</city>
    <city>Berlin</city>
    <city>Paris</city>
  </region>
  <region>
    <city>Tokyo</city>
  </region>
</world>

If you specify "region" as the XML Repeat Tag, then this component splits the XML document into three records, each containing a property named world/region/city. In the case of the second record, this is a three-item array property.

Notes:
  • If Preserve Hierarchy is False, XML attributes also become properties. In this case, the property name follows the same scheme as the text valueproperties, but the final attribute name is delimited by a period ("."). For example, the element <city latitude="40.77"> results in a property named world/region/city.latitude with value "40.77".
  • XML Repeat Tag should include a prefix if there is one in the tag. For example, if the element is written as <b:species>, define the repeat element name as "b:species".
  • When encountering nested elements, only the top-level entry is returned. For example, a repeat tag element is skipped if it appears in the XML as the child of an element also identified by the XML Repeat Tag, such as <element-name><element-name></element-name></element-name>.
See Also:
  • For reading XML files in the SciTegic format, use XML Reader (SciTegic).
  • For reading generic XML files, use XML Reader (Generic).

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.name: PropertyNames
sci:arg.sci:help: The names of the one or more properties to separate and return as separate data records. If no property names are given, then all properties with multiple values will be unmerged. If multiple properties are unmerged, the number of unmerged records is the number of values of a property with the maximum number of values.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: Large Data Records
sci:arg.sci:help: When individual data records are very large as may be the case with Images, Sequence Analysis or Gene Expression Data, or Text Analytics annotations, this component can easily run out of memory on 32-bit systems. If each of your records are particularly large, setting this parameter to true will significantly reduce the memory usage of the component but with the tradeoff of slower performance.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Separates data records containing array properties into individual records with one array value per record

Each incoming data record with more than one value for the property or properties specified by PropertyNames is duplicated for each of the values. For example, an input data record with three values will generate three output data records. Each output record will contain one of the values for the PropertyNames property, and all other properties will be identical.

Large Data Records: When individual data records are very large as may be the case with Images, Sequence Analysis or Gene Expression Data, or Text Analytics annotations, this component can easily run out of memory on 32-bit systems. If each data record is particularly large, setting Large Data Records to true will significantly reduce the memory usage of the component but with the tradeoff of slower performance.

Notes:
  • If no property names are given, then all properties with multiple values are unmerged. In this case, unexpected occurrences of arrays in a property will cause unintentional unmerge operations. Try to specify a value for PropertyNames if possible.
  • If multiple unmerge properties are specified, the number of data records that result from unmerging a given incoming data record is equal to the number of values of the unmerge property that has the most values. That is, if two unmerge properties, "A" and "B" are specified where A has 5 values and B has 7 values, then 7 data records will result. The first 5 records will contain, in order, the 5 values of A. For the last two records, A will be undefined. All other properties will be duplicated on each record.
Data records containing the separated values for the property or properties specified.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Data Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The SQL Database Data Source Name -- i.e. the specification of the database to be used by this SQL component. There are three choices: 1) The name of a pipeline pilot Data Source (DS Name). This data source is defined on the pipeline pilot server (using the Data Source Editor dialog from the client or the Administration Portal). The Data Source can reference either an ODBC or JDBC database connection. 2) The name of a connection defined on a previous SQL Open Connection component. Use the form (Name=Connection Name). Either the Data Source or Connection name can be specified from the dialog by clicking the '...' button 3) Alternatively this field can be an ODBC driver specification that eliminates the need to create a DSN or Data Source on the server. As an example: DRIVER=Scitegic Oracle 6.0;AUT=0;EDP=1;PRR=1;HOST=dbHost;UID=dbUser;PWD=dbPwd;PORT=1521;SID=dbSid (the AUT=0, ... settings reflect the correct defaults of 'Application Using Threads', 'Enable SQLDescribeParam' and 'Procedure Returns Results').

sci:arg.name: Authentication Method
sci:arg.sci:help:
Determines which method to use during authentication with the data source.
  • Use Username and Password Parameters: Use the values provided by the component's Data Source Username and Data Source Password parameters.
  • Use Pipeline Pilot Credentials: Use the username and password that were provided when the user logged into Pipeline Pilot. NOTE: if the Data Source Username parameter is provided, its value will override the user's logged in username.

sci:arg.name: Data Source Username
sci:arg.sci:help:
The username used to connect to the supplied Data Source.

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use Username and Password Parameters', then this parameter must be filled in to log into the database (unless it is part of the Data Source).

If the Authentication Method is set to 'Use SciTegic Credentials', then this parameter can be left empty and the logged in user name is used. As an override option, if the user name is filled in, this user name will be used along with the user's Pipeline Pilot password.

sci:arg.name: Data Source Password
sci:arg.sci:help: The password used to authenticate with the Data Source. This parameter is disabled if Authentication Method is not set to 'Use Username and Password Parameters' or it is specified in the Data Source.

sci:arg.name: SQL Statement
sci:arg.sci:help:
An SQL SELECT statement with parameter substitution in the where clause. For each input record the SELECT statement will be executed with the appropriate parameters substituted in for the ? markers. E.g.
SELECT COL1, COL2, etc.. FROM MTABLE WHERE COL1 = ?
sci:arg.sci:value:
SELECT iv.entity_instance_id, iv.state_name, iv.entity_type_id , iv.entity_type_name, (SELECT count (state_name) FROM entity_workflow_view WHERE entity_type_id = iv.entity_type_id AND version = current_version AND state_name = ?) state_count FROM entity_instances_index_view iv WHERE iv.entity_instance_id = ?
/*SELECT * FROM entity_instances_index_view WHERE ENTITY_INSTANCE_ID = ?*/

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to process (all if value is empty).

sci:arg.name: SQL Parameter Mapping
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of property names to map to variables (denoted by "?") in the SQL Statement. There must be the same number of properties in SQL Parameter Mapping as there are variables in the SQL Statement.

sci:arg.name: Select Behavior
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the SELECT statement returns multiple values. * Append Values: All values are appended onto array properties on one data record. (NULLs will be represented as empty values in the arrays). * Multiple Data: Multiple data records are returned, one for each SELECT record

sci:arg.name: Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
If a Batch Size greater than one is specified, the component uses a batched approach to performing the select. A batch of records is cached and a composite where clause (SQL IN clause) is built. In batch mode only a single where clause condition (mapped parameter) is allowed. Specify the SQL statement in the normal fashion (the batching is handled automatically). For instance: SELECT ID1, NAME from tab WHERE ID1 = ? becomes SELECT ID1, NAME from tab WHERE ID1 IN (?, ?, ?) where the number of ? is dictated by the batch size and the same value (in this case ID1) from each of the input records is mapped to each of these parameters in turn. Note:
  • Because the records are processed in a batch, it is necessary to match each returned record with the correct input record. To do this it is required that the output record have a property (e.g. ID1) with the same name and value as the input mapping parameter property.

sci:arg.name: Cache Persistence Mode
sci:arg.sci:help:
For performance it can be convenient to cache the results of a database query to prevent the need to keep returning to the database (be careful if the data changes since your cache might get out of date). The first time a search value (from the SQL Parameter Mapping property) is encountered, a query is made against the database; subsequently the match(es) are returned from a cache. This cache handles the different cases where there is no match, one match or more than one match for a given search value. There are three different modes for the persistence of the cache:
  • None -- the default; no caching is performed for this query
  • Protocol -- the cache is retained for the duration of the protocol (the same cache query field against the same cache during the protocol execution will use the cache)
  • Memory -- this cache persists while the pooled SciSvr process remains running. This could be for multiple hours so be careful if data can change, since the cache will get stale.
Note:
  • A Cache Persistence Mode can be specified whether or not the Batch Size is greater than 1.

sci:arg.name: Cache Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the cache if a Cache Persistence Mode other than None is specified. This is the name that uniquely identifies this cache. Make sure that the cache names for two different queries are different otherwise strange results will ensue (seemingly randomly results from one query will appear for the other). This is particularly a concern for Cache Persistence Mode = Memory where caches from different protocols might coexist in the same SciSvr process.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: Return Native Types
sci:arg.sci:help: If true, Pipeline Pilot creates a property with the type that matches the column type in the database. If false, Pipeline Pilot creates a property of type String.

sci:arg.name: Fetch Size
sci:arg.sci:help: When retrieving data from JDBC data sources, the Fetch Size can be specified to give a hint to the JDBC driver for now many rows to return from the database on each call. Setting this to large value (e.g. 1000) can use more memory and delay the return of the first record but will also significantly improve performance if the database is located over a high latency connection from the Pipeline Pilot Server.

sci:arg.name: Separate Connection
sci:arg.sci:help:
If True, create a separate connection for this SQL component irrespective of the Data Source and username/password. If False, all components in the complete protocol with the same Data Source and optional username/password (that have Separate Connection set to False) share the same database connection.

NOTE: in general it is recommended to keep this parameter False and have a single connection to avoid the overhead of opening and closing multiple connections. Also if some SQL components are placed into a Run to Completion sub protocol, it is recommended to have an SQL Open Connection component outside the subprotocol to avoid repeatedly opening and closing the database connection.

sci:arg.name: Unicode
sci:arg.sci:help: Set this parameter to true to enable the retrieval of unicode, e.g. Kanji, characters. Set this to false to disable it.

sci:arg.name: JavaClass
sci:arg.sci:help: The class that implements the com.scitegic.pilot.Component interface.

sci:arg.name: Use Package
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the package that may be used to locate the Java binary files needed by the Java plug-in component.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: DataActionOnError
sci:arg.sci:help: When a General or DataType error occurs during processing: LeaveData: The data is passed unalterd ClearData: The data is cleared before being passed (an empty data item) DeleteData: The data is deleted and not passed

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Joins data from an SQL (ODBC or JDBC) data source with streaming data

This component executes an SQL select statement against an SQL Data Source for each data record it receives. Any properties retrieved are appended to the streaming record. In case multiple records with properties are retrieved from the SQL source, only the last occurrence is appended. The following sample SQL statement searches for a molecular record in the SQL source using a canonical smiles and retrieves the id and logp properties. These properties are appended to the data record in the data stream. If more than one record is retrieved, multiple properties are appended: SELECT id, logp FROM TableName WHERE Canonical_Smiles = ? The question mark is used as a place holder and will be replaced by values on the data record according to the value in "SQL Parameter Mapping." This value needs to be a comma separated list of property names and must be specified in the same order as you would want them to replace the question marks in the select statement. There must be the same number of question marks in the select statement as there are values in the parameter mapping. A valid value for 'SQL Parameter Mapping' and the above select statement would be 'canonical_smiles'.

See Also:

  • For an overview of database integration, see the Database Integration Guide
SELECT COL1, COL2, etc.. FROM MTABLE WHERE COL1 = ?

Notes:

Generates and displays an HTML table page of data records, with one record per row. Each property becomes a column in the table and each value a cell.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Creates a table in a report by collecting data records and displaying them in rows and columns

There are three ways you can create tables:

  • Auto-generated: Quickly build a table by adding one Table component in a report, immediately following data (i.e., blue) components). The Table component takes your data sources and creates one column for each property on your data stream. The table includes some pre-set formats to save you time.
  • Column-generated: You specify the content of your data source that should be used in the table. For each data property to include, add a component defining the content (e.g., Text or a chart component, plus a separate Column component for each column of the table to be created. Branch the data source to each pair of content/Column components and then pipe all of them into a single Table component. Each column is added to the table in the order it is shown visually in the protocol (top to bottom). Each column in a table must have the same number of rows.
  • In-line: Similar to Column-generated but instead of branching the data for each column of the table, place the "content" components in the sequence for the final table and then pipe this into a Table component. In each content component, use the Column Settings components to define column header and cell options.

See Also:

  • Report Design Essentials
Input can be raw data records, column objects or a sequence of Reporting components.
A data record representing the table is sent to the pass port.
